preface.title: Contributors to this textbook
preface.p:
Rabinoff contributed all of the figures, the demos, and the technical aspects of the project, as detailed below.
The textbook is written in XML and compiled using a variant of Robert Beezer's MathBook XML, with modifications by Rabinoff.
The mathematical content of the textbook is written in LaTeX, then converted to HTML-friendly SVG format using a collection of scripts called PreTeX: this was coded by Rabinoff and depends heavily on Inkscape for pdf decoding and FontForge for font embedding. The figures are written in PGF/TikZ and processed with PreTeX as well.
The demonstrations are written in JavaScript+WebGL using Steven Wittens' brilliant framework called MathBox.
All source code can be found on GitHub. It may be freely copied, modified, and redistributed, as detailed in the appendix entitled GNU Free Documentation License.

preface.title: History of the UoN edition
preface.p:
There are several variants of this textbook available.
You are viewing the University of Nottingham (UoN) edition of this book, rewritten by Ulrik Buchholtz for use in COMP1043 Mathematics for Computer Scientists 2.
This edition in turn grew out of the Duke edition, which was rewritten by Joe Rabinoff for use in Math 218D-1 at Duke University.
The Georgia Tech Edition has material on linear transformations and similar matrices, but does not cover the SVD or PCA. It was designed for use as the textbook for Math 1553 at the Georgia Institute of Technology.
The UBC Edition by Ben Williams is similar to the Georgia Tech Edition.
